body.p: This topic contains reuable fragments for the installation topics. The reuse strategy is to ensure that key values can be edited and compared in one place. We reuse in big chunks as reusing highly granular pieces just makes things hard to edit without any real maintainability win. In some cases, content that fits in only one topic is still included here and conrefed into the topic to keep all the information, such as requirements, in one file for ease of editing.

section.title: Installation requirements reusables
section.p: In this section, the reusable element is the <dd> element of each <dlentry>. Where the requirement is the same across platform, there is one entry per requirement that is used in all platforms. Where there are different requirements per platform, the id of the reusable <dd> element is in the form requirement.platoform, for instance, "memory.windows".

requires Java. If you use the native Windows installer, will be installed with its own copy of Java. If you use the all platforms installer, your system must have a compatible Java virtual machine installed.
supports only official and stable Java Virtual Machines with the version number or later (the recommended version is 1.6.0) from Oracle, formerly Sun Microsystems (available at http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html). may work with JVM implementations from other vendors, but there is no guarantee that other implementations will work with future updates and releases. does not work with the GNU libgcj Java Virtual Machine.
uses the following rules to determine which installed version of Java to use:
If the Windows environment variables JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME are set, it uses the Java version pointed to by those variables.
If JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME are not set, and you used the native Windows installer, which insalls a version of Java as part of the installation, the version in the jre subdirectory of the installation directory is used.
If JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME are not set and your installation does not include the jre subdirectory, looks for Java in the standard location.
If JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME are not set and your installation does not include the jre subdirectory, and Java is not installed in the standard location, the version of Java pointed to by your PATH environment variable is used.
